speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: O is the observation vector at each time point.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if you just had one binary sensor, O would be a 0 or 1.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If you had eight float sensors, it would be eight float numbers.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: S is a vector carried through time, each time point, of the latent states.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So let's say we're talking about temperature in the room, thermometer, observations, latent temperature, hidden state S, agent's estimate of hidden state S.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: a is a matrix that has um rows and columns corresponding to o and s a is a mapping between o and s and so it can be used to start with s and then emit a distribution of expected observations or it could be taking in an observation conditioning upon an observation like base theorem does and then updating um a hidden state belief
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: D has the same dimensionality as S being carried through time.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So D is just like a vector.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's kind of like T zero.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It just starts the chain going and it gives you S at the first time point.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then B is a transition matrix that has edges and rows and columns, edges, of the dimensionality of S. Because it maps S at t minus 1 to S at t. So this is a standard hidden Markov model.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Ambiguity matrix A between hidden states and observations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Transition matrix B between states at times.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: There's no action in this model yet.

text: So PI sums up to one.

text: It could be sampled from, or it could be just pick the highest number.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But pi intervenes with a policy in B. And so while previously B was just a single matrix going from S of T minus 1 to S of T, now B is going to be having a matrix slice for every single affordance that we have.
